In this view, bipolarity is symmetric again, as and 1-can be indifferently exchanged. Namely, 1-is interpreted as another standard (potential) possibility distribution, which is not the case with the previous semantics in terms of meta-epistemic states. In particular (A c ) (resp. 1 -(A)) is just the degree of necessity (resp. possibility) of event A computed from possibility distribution 1 -. Moreover, clouds , clearly contain the same information as clouds 1 -, 1 -, so that negation does not mean much in this framework. Moreover the case when = is called "thin cloud'' and it represent the maximally informative case, corresponding to the Atanassov style embedding of fuzzy sets in his orthopairs. The same conjunction and disjunction of orthopairs as in Section 9.3 are sanctioned by the cloud approach, but conjunction only partially captures the probabilistic semantics this time: indeed, for instance P(min( 1 , 2 )) ⊂ P( 1 ) ∩ P( 2 ), generally.

div.head: Bipolar preference
div.p: Finally another interpretive framework for IVFSs and Atanassov orthopairs is in preference modelling. Consider S as a set of criteria, and (s) the rating of some alternative with respect to criterion s. This rating belongs to a bipolar scale [0, 1] where 0.5 represents indifference, 1 excellence, and 0 total failure to satisfy the criterion. In that case, IVFSs clearly capture the idea of imprecise rating, as the idea of infinite precision does not sound realistic in this kind of context. This form of uncertainty has sometimes been described in terms of Atanassov orthopairs in multicriteria decision processes [115]. Then, the Atanassov terminology in this case is uselessly misleading as it is just another encoding of interval-valued computations. It only makes uncertainty processing more opaque than the IVFS setting.

However a purely bipolar view of decision evaluation is at odds with this kind of interpretation. First, even when is precise, the use of a bipolar evaluation scale may lead to a bipolar handling of the decision process, distinguishing between negative arguments against an alternative (those elements s with (s) < 0.5) and positive arguments in favour of this alternative (those elements s with (s) > 0.5), and handling the two sides separately in further information aggregation procedures (see [116][117][118] in the numerical setting, and [119] in the qualitative setting).

A quite different approach consists in considering two points of view on evaluating alternatives, by listing, on the one hand, constraints that such alternatives should satisfy, and, on the other hand, a set of goals (or desires) that should preferably be attained. In this view, S is a set of alternatives, (s) is the extent to which alternative s is feasible (according to all constraints), and (s) to what extent it is preferred (according to all goals). The inequality (s) ≤ (s) mirrors the fact that it is more demanding to be preferred than to be feasible. Under this view, the IVFS [ , ] does not express any kind of uncertainty, and 1 -(s) is the extent to which an alternative s should be rejected as unfeasible. It leads to combination operations that differ from those inspired by the IVFS setting but agree with the possibilistic bipolar setting: it is clear that an alternative satisfies two constraints 1 and 2 if and only if it satisfies at least the constraint min( 1 , 2 ) (feasibility is decreased), and that the satisfaction increases as more goals are attained so that the degree of satisfaction induced by 1 and 2 is at least max( 1 (s), 2 (s)). This asymmetric bipolar view, developed in more details in [120] does not match Atanassov calculus.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: This paper is a plea for significance when using fuzzy sets as a modelling tool. As such, a fuzzy set is an abstract mathematical entity and its proper use in practice needs a proper interpretive framework. Noticeably, sets, whether fuzzy or not, should be differently handled when they represent objective entities and when they model incomplete knowledge about an ill-known precise entity. In particular, fuzzy sets viewed as possibility distributions, should be handled in some kind of possible worlds semantics, as they represent mutually exclusive elements. However, the role of fuzziness is not always to capture uncertainty, just to make Boolean notions gradual, for instance uncertainty, in the case of possibility theory. The distinction between ontic and epistemic interpretations of sets (that are viewed as a conjunction or a disjunction of elements) is important when applying the mathematics of standard fuzzy sets to real problems, and it becomes crucial to keep it in mind when studying higher-order fuzzy sets where membership grades are themselves intervals or fuzzy sets of membership values. In particular, insofar as higher-order fuzzy sets are supposed to represent uncertainty about lower-order fuzzy sets, straightforward interval arithmetic extensions of fuzzy set algebras achieve a poor approximation of the process of reasoning under such uncertainty, a process that cannot rely on a compositional calculus.

Atanassov's "intuitionistic'' fuzzy sets are shown to be somewhat misleading for several reasons. It has been repeatedly said that the intuitionistic nature of this construction is dubious, because the Atanassov system is isomorphic to algebras of IVFSs. Interpreting Atanassov orthopairs just in terms of ill-known membership functions thus makes orthopairs of membership functions just another encoding of interval-valued fuzzy sets. The most natural interpretation of Atanassov system is in terms of bipolarity, whereby membership and non-membership functions correspond to independent and consistent pieces of positive and negative information or preference. While the epistemic understanding of interval-valued fuzzy sets can be captured by type II (symmetric) bipolarity, there is another view whereby pairs of membership and non-membership functions as considered more informative than single membership functions, contrary to the IVFS-based uncertain fuzzy set view. However, the corresponding extensions of fuzzy set-theoretic operations to orthopairs of membership functions are then generally at odds from the IVFS-like connectives that Atanassov proposed.

For instance, if a quantity x is only known to lie between a and b > a, considering these bounds as ill-known (for instance a ∈ [a -, a + ], b ∈ [b -, b + ]) sounds like an overly precise representation involving two levels of knowledge: as [a, b] is an epistemic interval, the pair ([a -, a + ], [b -, b + ]) then represent meta-epistemic knowledge that can be useful if one has to reason about partial ignorance concerning x, i.e. propagating uncertainty about epistemic state [a, b], not if we have to propagate the uncertainty pervading the value of x. In the latter case one may adopt [a -, b + ] as a conservative representation of our knowledge about x.
